title: How OpenAI Builds AI Agents That Think and Act [Josh Tobin] - 730

um I think that the misconception that a
lot of folks have about agents
is before I came back to OpenAI um had
been had spent a little bit of time
tinkering buil building agents on top of
LM APIs and um the problem that we ran
into which I think is the problem pretty
much everyone runs into when they try to
build uh their own agents you know using
like workflows on top of LM API calls is
that um it's very tempting to think oh
you LMS are are good at kind of making
point predictions, making decisions. Um,
and so we build a workflow around this
LLM. Then we can sort of automate a
process and uh take a bunch of decisions
and turn it into something that just
happens on its own. But I think what a
lot of us found trying to do this is
that um the temptation is there because
you can create a demo of this very very
quickly that looks great. Um but then
when you try to actually um deploy this
and get people to you know stop uh doing
this work themselves and instead
delegate it to an agent um you start to
run into all kinds of edge cases and uh
failure modes and getting the getting
things to work reliably is really hard.
Um and sort of the root cause of the
problem is that LMS most LLMs um
historically have not been trained to do
agentic work. And what that means is
that at any given step of the process,
maybe they're relatively accurate
because they're pretty smart general
purpose AI systems. Um, but as you run a
process that requires many steps, the
small errors at one step um compound as
you take multiple steps. So even if
you're, you know, 90% accurate on one
step, if you have to take 10 steps, um,
then your accuracy will fall off. Um and
so that's I think kind of the core
challenge of um building agents on top
of traditional LLMs. Um the missing
ingredient has been that we um need to
directly train these agents end to end
to do these workflow like tasks. Um by
doing that you can train the agents in
such a way that they see failures during
their training and they learn to recover
from those failures. So even if each
step is only, you know, 90% accurate or
95% accurate, now the model has seen
what it looks like to fail at that step
and it's able to reroute itself. It's
able to think, oh, this doesn't look
right. Like, let me go back and try that
again. Um, do you have a canonical
example that kind of illustrates this
problem? Yeah. Um, so a good example of
this would be like uh if you are
um you know if you're trying to kind of
like uh build an agent that um does
research for you. So if you uh um if you
do a single web search and maybe you get
the search term wrong, like the user
doesn't know what exactly what to search
for. So you try to search for terms that
seem relevant and you start to pull back
a bunch of docs that don't have
information that really gets to the
heart of the problem. Um then a naive
agent might just get confused by that
and they might think well okay that I
searched for the term that I thought
that they meant and all these docs are
irrelevant so maybe this is you know um
maybe maybe what the user asked for
doesn't make sense or maybe I need to go
down this other rabbit hole. Whereas an
agent that's trained to do web research
um and has been uh trained using
reinforcement learning to sort of
uh be good at this this um multi-step
process will in its training have seen
many instances where it searched for the
wrong term and the training has
incentivized it to learn to recover from
those instances and instead go back and
think oh you know I searched for this
term but I got results that weren't
relevant. Maybe that means I had the
wrong search term. So, let me go, you
know, try to try again and pick a
different one. And so, the key is really
like um reasoning models uh powered that
are trained end to end to solve the
kinds of tasks that users need them to
solve um using reinforcement learning so
that they're able to kind of like see
these multi-step processes um see the
kinds of failures that happen um in
training and learn to recover from them.
It strikes me that the
um the the creation of models that are
specifically designed to do this is one
powerful difference uh that we're seeing
in this new generation of models, but
also it's like a collapsing of
capability
uh a bunch of stuff around the model
that was trying to like keep it in the
the right path to just like making the
model better.
um you know
